description: Fit a constant Rossby number model to the short-period edge of the LAMOST-McQuillan sample.
instructions: 1. Load the LAMOST-McQuillan cross-matched data from `lamostmcq` (derived from `kepler_lamost.parquet` and `mcquillan2014_table1.parquet`).
2. Select stars with $\log g > 4.1$ to focus on main-sequence stars.
3. Approximate the short-period edge by computing the 10th percentile of rotation periods ($P_{rot}$) in overlapping $T_{eff}$ bins.
4. Use 100 bootstrapped resamples, leaving out 50% of the data each time to estimate uncertainties.
5. Use $T_{eff}$ bins centered every 20 K between 4000 K and 7000 K with half-widths of 100 K.
6. Omit stars with calculated Rossby number $Ro > 5/3$ during the percentile calculation, where $Ro = P_{rot}/\tau_{cz}(T_{eff})$ using Equations \ref{eq:1} and \ref{eq:2}.
7. Compute the final short-period edge curve as the mean of the bootstrapped 10th percentile values.
8. Fit a constant Rossby number model to this edge curve in the range $4500$ K $\leq T_{eff} \leq 5800$ K using MCMC.

9. Use the model: $P_{rot}(Ro, T_{eff}) = Ro \times \tau_{cz}(T_{eff} + T_{sys})$, where $\tau_{cz}$ is given by Equation \ref{eq:2}: $\tau_{cz}(T_{eff}) = 314.24 \times \exp(-(T_{eff} / 1952.5 \text{ K}) - (T_{eff} / 6250 \text{ K})^{18}) + 0.002$.
10. Use the likelihood function defined in Equation \ref{eq:3}, with variance $s_n^2 = \sigma^2 + f^2 \times P_{rot}(Ro, T_{eff} + T_{sys})^2$ (Equation \ref{eq:4}).
11. Assume $\sigma$ corresponds to a 10% fractional uncertainty on the percentile curve $P_{rot}$ values.
12. Use uniform priors: $Ro \in (0.1, 10)$, $f \in (0, 10)$, and $T_{sys} \in (-1000 \text{ K}, 1000 \text{ K})$.
13. Run MCMC sampling using \texttt{emcee} with 32 walkers for $10^5$ steps, ensuring convergence by checking autocorrelation lengths.
14. Extract the posterior samples for the Rossby number parameter from the MCMC chain.
15. Report the median posterior value for the Rossby number ($Ro$) as the final result.
output_justification: Table 1, row 'lamostmcq 10th Prot pctl.', column 'Ro'. Result is 0.37 +/- 0.02.
